lines.content: Elaina is the ultimate personal assistant chatbot.
Prerequisites: JDK 11, update IntelliJ to the most recent version.
1. Open IntelliJ (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project in IntelliJ as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 11** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
1. After that, locate the `src/main/java/com/lirc572/ip/Starter.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run ...`. If the setup is correct, you should see a GUI window pop up.
## Setting up in Visual Studio Code
Prerequisites: JDK 11, update Visual Studio Code to the most recent version.
1. Open the project in VS Code as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `Select Folder`.
1. If there is a prompt asking you to install the recommended extensions, click `Install`.
1. After that, open a terminal in the project directory and run `./gradlew run`. If the setup is correct, you should see a GUI window pop up.

# build for production and launch server
details: An all-in-one chatbot with a cute look and personality :)
details: Runs on all major desktop Operating Systems

We recommend developing Elaina with [IntelliJ Idea](#setup-for-intellij-idea) or [Visual Studio Code](#setup-for-visual-studio-code). Depending on which one you prefer, follow one of the sections below.
Elaina's documentation uses [VitePress](https://vitepress.vuejs.org/), hosted on [Netlify](https://www.netlify.com/). The documentation sources are under the `/docs` directory.

VitePress is used so that we can add custom [Vue.js components](https://vuejs.org/v2/guide/single-file-components.html) in the documentation. VitePress is simply awesome. We recommand using it for all future technical documentations.
We use a simple [Netlify function](https://docs.netlify.com/functions/overview/) to create an API that provides a dowloadable link to the latest JAR release of Elaina.
[Node.js](https://nodejs.org/) version >= 12.0.0 is required to preview or build the documentation.
We use `yarn` to manage Node dependencies, but if you have a strong reason to use `npm` instead, make sure you do not commit your `package-lock.json`.
### Run a Development Server of the Documentation
Then follow your command line output to open one of the preview URLs in your browser.
Then the static website will be generated under the `/docs/.vitepress/dist` directory.
# Make sure you run yarn build before this
It would launch a server that serves the content under the `/docs/.vitepress/dist` directory.
- `docs/.vitepress/components/DownloadLink.vue` is a Vue.js component that calles our Netlify function to get the link to the latest release of Elaina executable.
- `docs/netlify/functions/jar_url.js` is the Netlify function that fetches the URL to the latest release of Elaina executable using GitHub REST API.

- `docs/CNAME` is there so that GitHub pages will automatically send a `301` response for requests made to the default GitHub pages URL to redirect to <elaina.lirc572.com> if GitHub pages is enabled. GitHub may send you an email about incorrect DNS records, but it can be ignored since we only enabled GitHub pages for its redirection function.
We use [GitHub Actions](https://docs.github.com/actions) for automated testing and release. You are advised to learn the basics of GitHub Actions before making changes to the GitHub workflows.
- `.github/workflows/unit-test.yml` runs unit tests with JUnit on push
- `.github/workflows/package.yml` creates a new release with an executable JAR file on push of tags with the name of `v*`
To create a new release, simply create a new tag with version number in the format of `v*`, then push the tag to GitHub. GitHub Actions will handle the rest for you~
Elaina works under Windows, Mac OSX and Linux, as long as you have a Java SE Runtime Environment of version 11 or above.
1. Move `Elaina.jar` to a desired location (note that a file named `tasks.data` will be created in the same folder to store data)
1. Double click on `Elaina.jar` or run `java -jar Elaina.jar` to open it
1. Type [commands](#commands) in the textfield at the bottom and send it by clicking on send button or pressing enter key
1. Exit when you are done by clicking on the close button at the top or typing `bye`
Now that you have a basic understanding of how to start using Elaina, you can head over to the [User Guide](/pages/user-guide)
Elaina is the ultimate personal assistant chatbot that can boost your productivity. It runs on all major Desktop Operating Systems.
Make sure you are running Java SE Version 11 or above. You can check your Java version in a terminal as follows:
Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM 18.9 (build 11.0.9+7-LTS, mixed mode)
Make sure your are not running on a Mac VM. If you are, try disabling hardware acceleration.
If you are running Elaina on Linux, it is possible that your system is missing some libraries required. Try installing `libgnome` and see if the problem is solved.
If you encounter any problems while using Elaina, feel free to contact our developers via [GitHub Issue](https://github.com/lirc572/ip/issues/new/choose)!
If you are new to Elaina, it is advised to read [Getting Started](/pages/getting-started) first!
- each command consists of **tokens** that can be:
- either a single word (characters without whitespaces)
- or some words surrounded by single or double quotation marks
- `[...]`: optional arguments (tokens between square brackets are not necessary)
- `<TASKNAME>`: a *token* that represents the name of the task
- `<DATETIME>`: a *token* that represents a date time in the format of `dd-mm-yyyy HH:MM` **(must be surrounded by single or double quotation marks because of the space in between)**
- `<REGEX>`: a *token* in the form of a [regular expression](https://www3.ntu.edu.sg/home/ehchua/programming/howto/Regexe.html)
- Create a new todo task with the specified name.
- Create a new event task with the specified name (and date time if provided).
- Create a new deadline task with the specified name (and date time if provided).
- Delete a saved task of the given number.
- List all tasks that have been added.
- URLs starting with `http` and `https` are automatically converted to clickable links
- each command consists of **tokens** that can be:
- either a single word (characters without whitespaces)
- or some words surrounded by single or double quotation marks
- `[...]`: optional arguments (tokens between square brackets are not necessary)
- `<TASKNAME>`: a *token* that represents the name of the task
- `<DATETIME>`: a *token* that represents a date time in the format of `dd-mm-yyyy HH:MM` **(must be surrounded by single or double quotation marks because of the space in between)**
- `<REGEX>`: a *token* in the form of a [regular expression](https://www3.ntu.edu.sg/home/ehchua/programming/howto/Regexe.html)
Below is a list of all supported commands in alphabetical order:
| deadline | `deadline <TASKNAME> [/by <DATETIME>]` | add a new deadline task                |
| done     | `done <NUM>`                           | mark a task as done                    |
| event    | `event <TASKNAME> [/at <DATETIME>]`    | add a new event task                   |
| find     | `find <REGEX>`                         | search tasks by task name (with regex) |
| todo     | `todo <TASKNAME>`                      | add a new todo task                    |
